In the early 20th century, a successful merchant is vexed by spending on advertising: _Half the money I spend on advertising is wasted; the trouble is, I don't know which half._

The problem is two-fold: advertising is ineffective, and it is hard to pin-point the source of the inefficiency.


Had John Wanamaker live to see today's world, would he maintain the same assertion on the unavoidable inefficiency of advertising? 

Wanamaker's adage is probably the most invoked quote in illustrating the neccesity of media attribution nowadays.
